user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CloseAllFiles:
```c
int32 OS_CloseAllFiles(void)
{
    int32            return_code;
    int32            close_code;
    OS_object_iter_t iter;

    return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

    OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, &iter);

    while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
    {
        /* call OS_close() on the entry referred to by the iterator */
        close_code = OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry(&iter, OS_FileIteratorClose);
        if (close_code != OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            return_code = close_code;
        }
    }

    OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, &iter);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The call passes the address of a local iterator (OS_object_iter_t) so the called function may initialize or modify the object pointed to by that pointer — this is allowed by Rule 17.8. Rule 17.8 would only be violated if the called function assigned to its pointer parameter (i.e. changed the pointer parameter itself), but there is no evidence of that in this call fragment.
